item.title: Graphing GUI (BETA)
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Wikipedia itself should not be used as a citation, but it is invaluable for pointing you to actual citations that you can use, so it is not useless at all.

Back on topic, good idea and nice work so far. Perhaps a neat feature would be to allow the user to put in bounds and you would fill in the graph between those bounds, similar to what a graphing calculator would produce.

Read full topic

item.title: Graphing GUI (BETA)
item.dc:creator: @yakman yakman
item.description:
@yakman wrote:

[quote=“the bank, post:19, topic:271320”][quote author=unlimitedorb link=topic=358047.msg2745856#msg2745856 date=1239628454]
Stop trying to use your pathetic “reputation” as a crutch for future posts. If you can’t effectively argue without having to rely on a perceived cushion of safety from previous posts, then you have no credibility with the situation in question.

Unlike you, I find that that citing more credible sources than myself lends greatly to any argument. As soon as you can cite some sources or statistics relating the use of Wikipedia to a jump or decline in intelligence quotient then by all means rant away! Until then, feel free to wallow in your failed attempt at a patronizing post.

Who started this Thesaurus/Wikipedia is a thing to be shunned attitude, anyway? Oh, that’s right… it was frank_! I think it’s high time frank_ started making lemonade from this lemon tree of idiocy that he worked so hard to farm.
[/quote]Wikipedia is not a reliable source of info simply because anyone can edit and add their own information.

You could make the argument that wikipedia staff reads over the edited articles, and will revert to a backup after the edit. However, wikipedia staff don’t know everything, so if it sounds like it is true than the edit is accepted.

And this, in its entirety, is why Wikipedia simply can’t be trusted as a proper source of information. I do however admit that wikipedia has its usefulness, but it should hold no weight in an argument. Actual written, confirmed and uneditable blogs or papers on the matter should be much more preferred.

As for thesauruses, what’s the point? They are retarded in nature, but even more retarded when applied to the internet.

Don’t bring frank_ into this, you are just trying to start a fight.[/quote]

for the bolded part, you can just scroll down most wikipedia articles and see its citations, they are normally made up of Actual written, confirmed and uneditable blogs or papers on the matter.

Read full topic

And this, in its entirety, is why Wikipedia simply can’t be trusted as a proper source of information. I do however admit that wikipedia has its usefulness, but it should hold no weight in an argument. Actual written, confirmed and uneditable blogs or papers on the matter should be much more preferred.

As for thesauruses, what’s the point? They are retarded in nature, but even more retarded when applied to the internet.

Don’t bring frank_ into this, you are just trying to start a fight.[/quote]
wikipedia is pretty secure,

  1. many popular pages are locked so only admins can edit them
  2. when a person makes a change for the first time it is automatically flagged for review
  3. it has the same advantages as open source, if someone who knows the topic very well sees an issue in it they can contribute and fix it making it better etc

item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

[quote=“the bank, post:19, topic:271320”][quote author=unlimitedorb link=topic=358047.msg2745856#msg2745856 date=1239628454]
Stop trying to use your pathetic “reputation” as a crutch for future posts. If you can’t effectively argue without having to rely on a perceived cushion of safety from previous posts, then you have no credibility with the situation in question.

Unlike you, I find that that citing more credible sources than myself lends greatly to any argument. As soon as you can cite some sources or statistics relating the use of Wikipedia to a jump or decline in intelligence quotient then by all means rant away! Until then, feel free to wallow in your failed attempt at a patronizing post.

Who started this Thesaurus/Wikipedia is a thing to be shunned attitude, anyway? Oh, that’s right… it was frank_! I think it’s high time frank_ started making lemonade from this lemon tree of idiocy that he worked so hard to farm.
[/quote]Wikipedia is not a reliable source of info simply because anyone can edit and add their own information.

You could make the argument that wikipedia staff reads over the edited articles, and will revert to a backup after the edit. However, wikipedia staff don’t know everything, so if it sounds like it is true than the edit is accepted.

And this, in its entirety, is why Wikipedia simply can’t be trusted as a proper source of information. I do however admit that wikipedia has its usefulness, but it should hold no weight in an argument. Actual written, confirmed and uneditable blogs or papers on the matter should be much more preferred.

As for thesauruses, what’s the point? They are retarded in nature, but even more retarded when applied to the internet.

Don’t bring frank_ into this, you are just trying to start a fight.[/quote]

en.wikipedia.org

Reliability of Wikipedia

The reliability of Wikipedia (predominantly of the English-language edition) has been frequently questioned and often assessed. The reliability has been tested statistically, through comparative review, analysis of the historical patterns, and strengths and weaknesses inherent in the editing process unique to Wikipedia. Incidents of conflicted editing, and the use of Wikipedia for 'revenge editing' (inserting false, defamatory or biased statements into biographies) have attracted publicity.[2

As a summary, you really think that an Encyclopedia written by many people who know what they are talking about is less accurate than one written by just a few people?

Read full topic

item.title: Graphing GUI (BETA)
item.dc:creator: @unlimitedorb unlimitedorb
item.description:
@unlimitedorb wrote:

[quote=“the bank, post:17, topic:271320”][quote author=unlimitedorb link=topic=358047.msg2745559#msg2745559 date=1239604733]

I’m done posting here, I get criticism no matter what. I’m going back to the JAVA forums; for christ sake STOP GIVING PEOPLE CRITICISM, if you really want to help people do it in a nice way.[br][br][size=1]Posted on: April 11, 2009, 08:30:49 am[/size][hr][quote author=io9 link=topic=358047.msg2734710#msg2734710 date=1238977737]
Chart != Graph…

I could care less, if you don’t like the class name CHANGE it.

Criticism is generally a good thing, unless you can’t handle it.
[/quote]

No.

There’s a distinction between constructive criticism and criticism in general. What io9 posted falls under the latter category. Posts like that are complete bullshit and are usually made by people who don’t have a damn clue as to what it is they’re talking about. It just so happens that io9 is a “non-contributing zero” and, as such, he needs to shut the hell up until he gets a clue.

Not that it matters, but I have TI-89 titanium graphing calculator. When I plot points, I plot points on a graph. Let’s see what Wikipedia has to say on the matter:

en.wikipedia.org

Graph of a function

In mathematics, the graph of a function f is, formally, the set of all ordered pairs (x, f(x)), such that x is in the domain of the function f, and, in practice, the graphical representation of this set. If the function input x, and the values f(x), are real numbers, the graph is a two-dimensional graph, and, for a continuous function, is a curve. If the function input x is an ordered pair (x1, x2) of real numbers, the graph is the collection of all pairs ((x1, x2), f(x1, x2)). These pairs can b...

If your world is so small that you can’t handle the concept of there being more than one interpretation for a word, then you have no business posting criticism of any kind.
[/quote]Stop posting Wikipedia links, it doesn’t make you look any smarter.[/quote]

Stop trying to use your pathetic “reputation” as a crutch for future posts. If you can’t effectively argue without having to rely on a perceived cushion of safety from previous posts, then you have no credibility with the situation in question.

Unlike you, I find that citing more credible sources than myself lends greatly to any argument. As soon as you can cite some sources or statistics relating the use of Wikipedia to a jump or decline in intelligence quotient then by all means rant away! Until then, feel free to wallow in your failed attempt at a patronizing post.

Who started this Thesaurus/Wikipedia is a thing to be shunned attitude, anyway? Oh, that’s right… it was frank_! I think it’s high time frank_ started making lemonade from this lemon tree of idiocy that he worked so hard to farm.

EDIT:

If you ever decide to make another shitty one-liner in the future, I hope you understand that comma splices don’t make you look any smarter.

1.) Learn the difference between an independent clause and a dependent clause.
2.) Learn the different ways in which two independent clauses can be connected.

Read full topic

item.title: Graphing GUI (BETA)
item.dc:creator: @Cheese_Police c|p
item.description:
@Cheese_Police wrote:

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Graph_(data_structure)

In computer science, a graph is a kind of data structure, specifically an abstract data type (ADT), that consists of a set of nodes (also called vertices) and a set of edges that establish relationships (connections) between the nodes.

This is relative to computer science, is it not?

Read full topic

item.title: Graphing GUI (BETA)
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

en.wikipedia.org

Chart

A chart is a graphical representation of data, in which "the data is represented by symbols, such as bars in a bar chart, lines in a line chart, or slices in a pie chart". A chart can represent tabular numeric data, functions or some kinds of qualitative structure and provides different info. The term "chart" as a graphical representation of data has multiple meanings: Charts are often used to ease understanding of large quantities of data and the relationships between parts of the data. Charts...

I have no idea where you are getting chart from. Hasn’t anyone here ever used a graphing calculator before?

Anyway, great work Killer-99-pkz.

Read full topic
